elements.content: Five new uranyl phenyldiphosphonate compounds have been synthesized using cations encapsulated by a variety of crown ethers (18-crown-6, 15-crown-5, and 12-crown-4) as structure directing agents under mild hydrothermal conditions. These compounds, [(H3O)@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·2H2O (U18C6-1), [K@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·4H2O (U18C6-2), [(H3O)@C10H20O5]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·4H2O (U15C5-1), and [(H3O)C8H16O4][(UO2)(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)]2 (U12C4-1) are all layered, while [(H3O)C8H16O4]{(UO2)3[(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)2C6H4(PO3H)2]} (U12C4-2) adopts a three-dimensional channel structure. U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1 are constructed from UO6F pentagonal bipyramids, whereas U12C4-1 and U12C4-2 have UO7 and UO6 units, respectively. The crystal structures corroborate the proposed C 3v and D 3d conformational symmetries observed in H3O+ and K+ crown ether inclusion complexes, respectively. These compounds fluoresce at room temperature and display a red shift of 35 nm compared to the luminescence spectrum of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate.

These compounds, [(H3O)@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}⋅2H2O (U18C6-1), [K@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}⋅4H2O (U18C6-2), [(H3O)@C10H20O5]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}⋅4H2O (U15C5-1), and [(H3O)C8H16O4][(UO2)(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)]2 (U12C4-1) are all layered, while [(H3O)C8H16O4]{(UO2)3[(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)2C6H4(PO3H)2]} (U12C4-2) adopts a three-dimensional channel structure. U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1 are constructed from UO6F pentagonal bipyramids, whereas U12C4-1 and U12C4-2 have UO7 and UO6 units, respectively. The crystal structures corroborate the proposed C 3v  and D 3d  conformational symmetries observed in H3O+ and K+ crown ether inclusion complexes, respectively. These compounds fluoresce at room temperature and display a red shift of 35 nm compared to the luminescence spectrum of uranyl nitrate hexahydrate.

elements.content: Five new uranyl phenyldiphosphonate compounds, [(H3O)@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·2H2O (U18C6-1), [K@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·4H2O (U18C6-2), [(H3O)@C10H20O5]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·4H2O (U15C5-1), [(H3O)C8H16O4][(UO2)(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)]2 (U12C4-1), and [(H3O)C8H16O4]{(UO2)3[(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)2C6H4(PO3H)2]} (U12C4-2) have been prepared under a mild hydrothermal route incorporating varieties of crown ethers to examine direct relationships between the sizes, shapes, charges (inclusion cations), and structures of the resulting compounds.

elements.content: Recent interest in the synthesis of oxoanion compounds of uranium is due, in part, to the potential for transforming the vast stores of depleted uranium waste into functional materials for addressing problems of safe disposal and remediation of nuclear waste. The preparation of these materials can capitalize on the structural richness of U(VI), which can be found to be coordinated in tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramidal environments, leading to countless new extended networks when combined with bridging oxoanions. Organic templates as well as inorganic cations are often used to direct the formation of different anionic uranyl oxoanion lattices. A small subset of these compounds have been shown to display useful properties, such as selective ion-exchange, ionic conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, magnetic ordering, and differential gas sorption. Systems designed from cations encapsulated by crown ethers are potentially important because they are highly selective for targeted metals, especially by varying the size of the cavity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recent interest in the synthesis of oxoanion compounds of uranium is due, in part, to the potential for transforming the vast stores of depleted uranium waste into functional materials for addressing problems of safe disposal and remediation of nuclear waste. The preparation of these materials can capitalize on the structural richness of U(VI), which can be found to be coordinated in tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramidal environments, leading to countless new extended networks when combined with bridging oxoanions. Organic templates as well as inorganic cations are often used to direct the formation of different anionic uranyl oxoanion lattices. A small subset of these compounds have been shown to display useful properties, such as selective ion-exchange, ionic conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, magnetic ordering, and differential gas sorption. Systems designed from cations encapsulated by crown ethers are potentially important because they are highly selective for targeted metals, especially by varying the size of the cavity.

elements.content: The structural chemistry of uranyl phenylphosphonates is very rich, displaying the first uranyl nanotubule that was isolated via the transformation of one-dimensional α- and β-uranyl phenylphosphonates upon exposure to Na+ or Ca2+ cations in aqueous solution. When Cs+ cations are used to template uranyl phenyldiphosphonate, a remarkable nanotubular compound results, Cs3.62H0.38{(UO2)4[C6H4(PO2OH)2]3[C6H4(PO3)2]F2}. Immersion of this compound in aqueous solution of soft monovalent cations results in exchange of the Cs+ cations. Cs+ cations on the interior of the nanotubules exchange at a different rate than those on the exterior. The use of the rigid benzenediphosphonate ligand also serves as columns in the construction of pillared three-dimensional framework structures containing the uranyl cation.

elements.content: As an expansion of our previous work, we have studied the effects of using cations encapsulated by crown ethers as structure directing agents. Hydronium, H3O+, and potassium cations are incorporated within the cavity of crown ethers to produce cation–crown ether inclusion complexes that play a vital role in controlling the geometry of the structures and also function in charge balancing. Herein we report the synthesis, structures, and spectroscopic characterization of these compounds, [(H3O)@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·2H2O (U18C6-1), [K@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·4H2O (U18C6-2), [(H3O)@C10H20O5]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}·4H2O (U15C5-1), [(H3O)C8H16O4][(UO2)(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)]2 (U12C4-1), and [(H3O)C8H16O4]{(UO2)3[(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)2C6H4(PO3H)2]} (U12C4-2).

elements.content: UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries), HF (48 wt %, Aldrich), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (95%, Epsilon Chimie), 18-crown-6 (≥99%, Aldrich), 15-crown-5 (98%, Aldrich), 12-crown-4 (98%, Aldrich), and KCl (99–100% Aldrich) were used as received. Reactions were run in PTFE-lined Parr 4749 autoclaves with a 23 mL internal volume. Distilled and Millipore filtered water with a resistance of 18.2 MΩ·cm was used in all reactions. Caution! While all the uranium compounds used in these studies contained depleted uranium salts, standard precautions were performed for handling radioactive materials, and all studies were conducted in a laboratory dedicated to studies on actinide elements.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O (98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries), HF (48 wt %, Aldrich), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (95%, Epsilon Chimie), 18-crown-6 (≥99%, Aldrich), 15-crown-5 (98%, Aldrich), 12-crown-4 (98%, Aldrich), and KCl (99-100% Aldrich) were used as received. Reactions were run in PTFE-lined Parr 4749 autoclaves with a 23 mL internal volume. Distilled and Millipore filtered water with a resistance of 18.2 MΩ⋅cm was used in all reactions.  Caution! While all the uranium compounds used in these studies contained depleted uranium salts, standard precautions were performed for handling radioactive materials, and all studies were conducted in a laboratory dedicated to studies on actinide elements.

elements.content: UO2(NO3)·6H2O (50.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (47.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), 0.5 mL of water, and very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave in the presence of either 18-crown-6 (26.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), 15-crown-5 (0.02 mL, 0.1 mmol), or 12-crown-4 (0.2–0.4 mL, 1.2–2.5 mmol) to produce the above compounds, respectively. After heating for 2 days at 150 °C, the autoclave was then cooled at an average rate of 5 °C/h to 25 °C. The resulting yellow products were thoroughly washed with warm water (to remove unreacted phosphonic acid), then rinsed with ethanol, and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. U18C6-2 was isolated by the same procedure above by adding KCl (10.4 mg, 0.1 mmol). A pure phase containing U12C4-2 was isolated by using 0.4 mL of 12-crown-4. Yellow tablets of the compounds U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 and yellow needles of U15C5-1 suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were formed. (Yields are U18C6-1 = 61% and U12C4-2 = 69% based on uranium.)
elements.clean_text:
U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U15C5-1, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2

UO2(NO3)⋅6H2O (50.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (47.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), 0.5 mL of water, and very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave in the presence of either 18-crown-6 (26.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), 15-crown-5 (0.02 mL, 0.1 mmol), or 12-crown-4 (0.2-0.4 mL, 1.2-2.5 mmol) to produce the above compounds, respectively. After heating for 2 days at 150 °C, the autoclave was then cooled at an average rate of 5 °C/h to 25 °C. The resulting yellow products were thoroughly washed with warm water (to remove unreacted phosphonic acid), then rinsed with ethanol, and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. U18C6-2 was isolated by the same procedure above by adding KCl (10.4 mg, 0.1 mmol). A pure phase containing U12C4-2 was isolated by using 0.4 mL of 12-crown-4. Yellow tablets of the compounds U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 and yellow needles of U15C5-1 suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were formed. (Yields are U18C6-1 = 61% and U12C4-2 = 69% based on uranium.)

elements.content: Single crystals of U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U15C5-1, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 were mounted on cryoloops and optically aligned on a Bruker APEXII Quazar CCD X-ray diffractometer using a digital camera. Initial intensity measurements were performed using either a IμS X-ray source or a 30 W microfocused sealed tube (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) with a monocapillary collimator. Standard APEXII software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The intensities of reflections of a sphere were collected by a combination of four sets of exposures (frames). Each set had a different φ angle for the crystal, and each exposure covered a range of 0.5° in ω. A total of 1464 frames were collected with an exposure time per frame of 10–30 s, depending on the crystal. SAINT software was used for data integration including Lorentz and polarization corrections. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The program suite SHELXTL was used for space group determination (XPREP), direct methods structure solution (XS), and least-squares refinement (XL). The final refinements included anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. Selected crystallographic information is listed in Table . Tables 2–6 report selected bond distances (Å) and angles, and can be found in the . Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and additional structural information are provided in the (CIF files).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

Single crystals of U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U15C5-1, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 were mounted on cryoloops and optically aligned on a Bruker APEXII Quazar CCD X-ray diffractometer using a digital camera. Initial intensity measurements were performed using either a IμS X-ray source or a 30 W microfocused sealed tube (Mo Kα, λ = 0.71073 Å) with a monocapillary collimator. Standard APEXII software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The intensities of reflections of a sphere were collected by a combination of four sets of exposures (frames). Each set had a different φ angle for the crystal, and each exposure covered a range of 0.5° in ω. A total of 1464 frames were collected with an exposure time per frame of 10-30 s, depending on the crystal. SAINT software was used for data integration including Lorentz and polarization corrections. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The program suite SHELXTL was used for space group determination (XPREP), direct methods structure solution (XS), and least-squares refinement (XL). The final refinements included anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. Selected crystallographic information is listed in Table . Tables 2-6 report selected bond distances (Å) and angles, and can be found in the . Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and additional structural information are provided in the  (CIF files).

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected for U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U15C5-1, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 on a Scintag θ–θ diffractometer equipped with a diffracted-beamed monochromatic set for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature in the angular range from 5° to 70° (2θ) with a scanning step width of 0.05° and a fixed counting time of 1 s/step. The collected patterns were compared with those calculated from single-crystal data using ATOMS and Mercury. The data are included in the .

The collected patterns were compared with those calculated from single-crystal data using ATOMS and Mercury. The data are included in the .

elements.content: Fluorescence and absorption data were acquired for all the compounds and UO2(NO3)2·6H2O from single crystals using a Craic Technologies UV–vis–NIR microspectrophotometer with a fluorescence attachment. The spectra were recorded in the range 450–650 nm at room temperature, and excitation was achieved using 365 nm light from a mercury lamp for the fluorescence spectroscopy. The absorption data can be found in the .
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Spectroscopy

Fluorescence and absorption data were acquired for all the compounds and UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O from single crystals using a Craic Technologies UV-vis-NIR microspectrophotometer with a fluorescence attachment. The spectra were recorded in the range 450-650 nm at room temperature, and excitation was achieved using 365 nm light from a mercury lamp for the fluorescence spectroscopy. The absorption data can be found in the .

elements.content: Infrared spectra were collected from single crystals of all the five compounds using a SensIR Technology IlluminatIR FT-IR microspectrometer. A single crystal of each compound was placed on a glass slide, and the spectrum was collected with a diamond ATR objective.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

Infrared spectra were collected from single crystals of all the five compounds using a SensIR Technology IlluminatIR FT-IR microspectrometer. A single crystal of each compound was placed on a glass slide, and the spectrum was collected with a diamond ATR objective.

elements.content: The cationic uptake properties of U18C6-1 and U12C4-2 were investigated with selected cations, Cs+/K+/Ag+ ions. A total of 15 mg crystals of the compounds above were placed in Teflon vials (8 mL), 5 mL of a 5 M solution of CsCl/KCl/AgNO3 was added, and the vials were then covered. The solution was mixed for 7 days with a mechanical shaker at room temperature and also at 70 °C. The mixture was filtered with filter paper, and the solids were air-dried at room temperature. Yellow crystals of U18C6-1 and U12C4-2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were recovered from the vial. These crystals were analyzed using both energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and re-examined using single crystal X-ray diffraction for elemental analysis and structural determinations.
elements.clean_text:
Ion-Exchange Studies

The cationic uptake properties of U18C6-1 and U12C4-2 were investigated with selected cations, Cs+/K+/Ag+ ions. A total of 15 mg crystals of the compounds above were placed in Teflon vials (8 mL), 5 mL of a 5 M solution of CsCl/KCl/AgNO3 was added, and the vials were then covered. The solution was mixed for 7 days with a mechanical shaker at room temperature and also at 70 °C. The mixture was filtered with filter paper, and the solids were air-dried at room temperature. Yellow crystals of U18C6-1 and U12C4-2 suitable for X-ray diffraction were recovered from the vial. These crystals were analyzed using both energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and re-examined using single crystal X-ray diffraction for elemental analysis and structural determinations.

elements.content: The addition of hydrofluoric acid to the reactions is essential to increase the crystallinity of the products. It also serves as a ligand in the preparation of U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1. U15C5-1, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 were isolated along with the known phase, [H3O]2{(UO2)6[C6H4(PO3)(PO2OH)]2[C6H4(PO2OH)2]2[C6H4(PO3)2]}(H2O)2. When 0.2 mL of 12-crown-4 was used, mixed phases of U12C4-1 were isolated as minor product and U12C4-2 as major product along with the known phase of uranyl diphosphonate, and pure U12C4-2 was prepared by increasing the amount of 12-crown-4 in the reaction to 0.4 mL. U15C5-1 was isolated with unidentifiable powders. Only two of the compounds, U18C6-1 and U12C4-2, were obtained as pure phases, as demonstrated by X-ray powder diffraction studies on all the compounds (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The addition of hydrofluoric acid to the reactions is essential to increase the crystallinity of the products. It also serves as a ligand in the preparation of U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1. U15C5-1, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 were isolated along with the known phase, [H3O]2{(UO2)6[C6H4(PO3)(PO2OH)]2[C6H4(PO2OH)2]2[C6H4(PO3)2]}(H2O)2. When 0.2 mL of 12-crown-4 was used, mixed phases of U12C4-1 were isolated as minor product and U12C4-2 as major product along with the known phase of uranyl diphosphonate, and pure U12C4-2 was prepared by increasing the amount of 12-crown-4 in the reaction to 0.4 mL. U15C5-1 was isolated with unidentifiable powders. Only two of the compounds, U18C6-1 and U12C4-2, were obtained as pure phases, as demonstrated by X-ray powder diffraction studies on all the compounds (see ).

elements.content: In a recently published perspective, crown ethers have been shown as good stabilizing ligands for oxonium ions (H3O+, H5O2 +, etc.). Complexes of 18-crown-6 and 15-crown-5 with H3O+ have been investigated under isolated conditions using infrared multiple photon dissociation (IRMPD) and DFT calculations for conformational assignment. These results are further corroborated by our crystal structures, as shown in Figure . Hydronium ion is almost a planar guest cation in 18-crown-6, confirming the proposed C 3v conformational symmetry. 15-crown-5 coordinates with hydronium ion to adopt a partially folded asymmetric pyramidal geometry. In aqueous solution, 18-crown-6 preferentially binds K+ compared to other alkali metals. Our result, [K@(18-crown-6)]+ complex, agrees with K+ having an optimal “fit” for the cavity of 18-crown-6, and the X-ray structure revealed the proposed D 3d conformational symmetry. These crystal structures further provide evidence into the emergence of chirality and symmetry in crown ether complexes. The flexibility of the crown ether backbone and symmetry constraints are of key relevance to the selective behavior of crown ethers toward various cations, which made them of importance for applications for selective ion-exchange. The H3O+ ion is suitably sized for the 18-crown-6 cavity and resides at the center of the macrocyclic cavity through hydrogen bonding interactions. For hydronium ion to reside within the 12-crown-4 cavity, the hydrogen bonding distances would have to be shorter than 2.8 Å (reported for O(hydronium)···O(18-crown-6) internuclear distances). Therefore, the hydronium ions are forced to reside outside the macrocylic cavity of 12-crown-4.
elements.clean_text:
Crown Ether Inclusion Complexes with H3O+ and K+ Ions

In a recently published perspective, crown ethers have been shown as good stabilizing ligands for oxonium ions (H3O+, H5O2 +, etc.). Complexes of 18-crown-6 and 15-crown-5 with H3O+ have been investigated under isolated conditions using infrared multiple photon dissociation (IRMPD) and DFT calculations for conformational assignment. These results are further corroborated by our crystal structures, as shown in Figure . Hydronium ion is almost a planar guest cation in 18-crown-6, confirming the proposed C 3v  conformational symmetry. 15-crown-5 coordinates with hydronium ion to adopt a partially folded asymmetric pyramidal geometry. In aqueous solution, 18-crown-6 preferentially binds K+ compared to other alkali metals. Our result, [K@(18-crown-6)]+ complex, agrees with K+ having an optimal "fit" for the cavity of 18-crown-6, and the X-ray structure revealed the proposed D 3d  conformational symmetry. These crystal structures further provide evidence into the emergence of chirality and symmetry in crown ether complexes. The flexibility of the crown ether backbone and symmetry constraints are of key relevance to the selective behavior of crown ethers toward various cations, which made them of importance for applications for selective ion-exchange. The H3O+ ion is suitably sized for the 18-crown-6 cavity and resides at the center of the macrocyclic cavity through hydrogen bonding interactions. For hydronium ion to reside within the 12-crown-4 cavity, the hydrogen bonding distances would have to be shorter than 2.8 Å (reported for O(hydronium)⋅⋅⋅O(18-crown-6) internuclear distances). Therefore, the hydronium ions are forced to reside outside the macrocylic cavity of 12-crown-4.

elements.content: U18C6-1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/n, and it has a layered structure consisting of two crystallographically unique uranyl cations; found within UO6F pentagonal bipyramids that are corner-shared uranyl dimers that are linked through the vertices by fluoride ions (Figure ). These uranyl dimers are bridged by the diphosphonate ligand through the PO3 moieties, resulting in uranyl phosphonate chains. These chains are further connected through the phenyl ring into sheets, as shown in Figure . Seated in the interlayer are two water molecules and hydronium–crown ether inclusion complexes that play a vital role in controlling the topology of the structures and also function in charge balancing.

Structure of [(H3O)@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}⋅2H2O (U18C6-1)

U18C6-1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/n, and it has a layered structure consisting of two crystallographically unique uranyl cations; found within UO6F pentagonal bipyramids that are corner-shared uranyl dimers that are linked through the vertices by fluoride ions (Figure ). These uranyl dimers are bridged by the diphosphonate ligand through the PO3 moieties, resulting in uranyl phosphonate chains. These chains are further connected through the phenyl ring into sheets, as shown in Figure . Seated in the interlayer are two water molecules and hydronium-crown ether inclusion complexes that play a vital role in controlling the topology of the structures and also function in charge balancing.

elements.content: The uranium coordinates with two nearly linear “yl” oxo atoms at the axial positions, resulting in a classical uranyl, UO2 2+ unit, with bond angles of 179.55(19)° and 179.28(18)°, and the average UO bond lengths for U(1) and U(2) units are 1.774(4) and 1.773(4) Å, respectively. The uranium units are coordinated with four oxygen and one fluorine atoms along the equatorial axis, with the U–O bond distances ranging from 2.324(4) to 2.421(4) Å, while the average U–F bond distance is 2.334(3) Å. The assignments of either F or O atoms were made on the basis of the improvement in the refinement factor to a lower percentage when the correct element was identified. When the wrong atom is selected, the thermal parameter becomes a nonpositive definite. Fluoride in the structure is also confirmed by EDS analysis. These distances result in bond-valence sums of 5.95 and 5.97 for U(1) and U(2), respectively; they are consistent with U(VI). The P–O bond distances are shorter than the P–OH bond distances, and the P–OH moieties are not coordinating to uranium centers. The P–O bond distances range from 1.482(5) to 1.592(4) Å. The P(1)O(5), P(2)O(9), P(3)O(11), and P(4)O(15) bonds correspond to the longest P–O bond distances of 1.569(4), 1.568(4), 1.584(5), and 1.592(4) Å respectively. They are terminal oxygen atoms and, therefore, sites of protonation.

elements.content: U18C6-2 also crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/n, and has a layered structure containing seven-coordinate uranium in the form of UO6F pentagonal bipyramids. These layers of uranyl phosphonates are more bent than in U18C6-1. The interlayer space is filled with planar potassium-crown ether inclusion complexes as shown in Figure . The potassium cations are incorporated within the cavity of the 18-crown-6 by K···O bonds as shown in Figure . This is essential so that the overall charge balance is maintained. The uranyl oxo group is extended outward and binds to the crown ether potassium cation, as it often does with alkali metal ions. Strong electrostatic interaction between potassium and uranyl oxygen and the symmetry of the crown ether are key features in this compound that play the role of structure directing, yielding slightly bent layered structures. A view along the [ac] plane (Figure ) shows corner-sharing uranyl cations that are connected through the diphosphonate moieties into sheets of uranyl phosphonate polyhedra.

Structure of [K@C12H24O6]{(UO2)2[C6H4(PO3H)2]2F}⋅4H2O (U18C6-2)

These layers of uranyl phosphonates are more bent than in U18C6-1. The interlayer space is filled with planar potassium-crown ether inclusion complexes as shown in Figure . The potassium cations are incorporated within the cavity of the 18-crown-6 by K⋅⋅⋅O bonds as shown in Figure . This is essential so that the overall charge balance is maintained. The uranyl oxo group is extended outward and binds to the crown ether potassium cation, as it often does with alkali metal ions. A view along the [ac] plane (Figure ) shows corner-sharing uranyl cations that are connected through the diphosphonate moieties into sheets of uranyl phosphonate polyhedra.

elements.content: The UO6F pentagonal bipyramids are bound by two terminal oxygen atoms along the axial position, and the average UO bond lengths for the U(1) and U(2) units are 1.777(6) and 1.776(6) Å, respectively. The equatorial U–O bonds range from 2.313(7) to 2.423(7) Å. There was no clear variation between the bond distances of uranyl oxygen involved in electronic interaction with K and others. The bond-valence sums for U(1) and U(2) are 5.95 and 5.91; they are consistent with U(VI). The P–O bond distances range from 1.493(7) to 1.590(7) Å. The P(1)O(7), P(2)O(9), P(3)O(13), and P(4)O(14) bond distances are 1.580(7), 1.590(7), 1.578(7), and 1.579(7) Å, respectively, and these distances reveal the presence of P–OH groups, which are the longest bonds and also correspond to terminal oxygen atoms from the phosphonate group. The potassium cation forms eight long contacts that range from 2.741(7) to 2.991(8) Å with six oxygen atoms from 18-crown-6 and two oxygen atoms from uranyl.

elements.content: U15C5-1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, triclinic space group P1̅ and contains uranium oxyfluoride groups. The layers of uranyl diphosphonates are similar to what we have observed in U18C6-2 except that they are more puckered (see Figure ). The partially folded [(H3O)@C10H20O5] + complexes are essential for charge balancing and filling of the interlayer space. The interlayer space is also filled with water molecules. A view along the [ac] plane (Figure ) reveals pentagonal bipyramids with corner-sharing fluoride ions to form uranyl dimers that are linked into uranyl chains by the phosphonate group. The UO6F pentagonal bipyramids are further connected through the phenyl ring into uranyl phosphonate sheets. The bound hydronium molecules form weak interactions with the uranyl oxygen atoms, thereby directing the topology of the structure.

elements.content: U12C4-1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, triclinic space group P1̅ and contains one crystallographically unique uranyl cation that is edge-shared via oxygen atoms into uranyl chains. A view along the [bc] plane (Figure ) reveals layers of uranyl phosphonates with the 12-crown-4 and hydronium molecules sitting within the interlayer space and connected through hydrogen bonding. Unlike 18-crown-6 and 15-crown-5 hydronium encapsulated complexes, the hydronium ion resides outside the cavity of 12-crown-4. The UO7 pentagonal bipyramid dimers are further connected through the phosphonate moiety into uranyl phosphonate sheets as shown in Figure .

elements.content: The uranium center coordinates with two nearly linear oxo atoms, resulting in a classical uranyl cation with a bond angle of 178.68(13)° and normal UO bond distances of 1.769(3) and 1.773(3) Å. The U–O bonds along the equatorial positions range from 2.290(3) to 2.553(3) Å. These distances result in bond-valence sums of 6.04, which is consistent with U(VI). The P–O bond distances range from 1.503(3) to 1.561(3) Å. The P–O bond distances P(1)O(5) and P(2)O(7) are 1.553(3) and 1.561(3) Å, respectively. These distances are longer than those of the other P–O bonds. These bond distances are indicative of the protonation of P–O bonds, and they are not involved in coordination to uranium centers. Some P–O bonds are partially protonated to balance the overall charges.

elements.content: U12C4-2 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, triclinic space group P1̅, similar to the two previously described compounds. The U12C4-2 structure is strikingly different from the other four compounds reported here. Instead of the usual layered structures, this compound adopts a three-dimensional framework structure with channels that run along the a axis as shown in Figure . These channels are filled by the disordered 12-crown-4 molecules, resulting in pore dimensions of approximately 13.19 × 13.16 × 13.07 Å3. The channels consist of six uranyl cations that are UO6 tetragonal bipyramidal geometry, a less common coordination environment in U(VI), and six phosphonate moieties as shown in Figure . This structure can be best described as a “ring-in-a-well”, with one end of the phosphonate moiety pointing toward the channel and the other away from the channel. The 12-crown-4, as well as the hydronium cation, are disordered in this compound, perhaps owing to static or dynamic rotational disorder of the 12-crown-4 molecule. This type of disorder is well-precedented. Attempts to model the disorder did not result in improved refinements or lower residual electron density. The triclinic space group was consistently selected by the xprep. We also tried to solve the structure using the trigonal/rhombohedral (R3̅) space group and found out that it was a false alarm.

Structure of [(H3O)C8H16O4]{(UO2)3[(PO3HC6H4PO3H0.5)2C6H4(PO3H)2]} (U12C4-2)

U12C4-2 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, triclinic space group P1̅, similar to the two previously described compounds. The U12C4-2 structure is strikingly different from the other four compounds reported here. Instead of the usual layered structures, this compound adopts a three-dimensional framework structure with channels that run along the a axis as shown in Figure . These channels are filled by the disordered 12-crown-4 molecules, resulting in pore dimensions of approximately 13.19 × 13.16 × 13.07 Å3. The channels consist of six uranyl cations that are UO6 tetragonal bipyramidal geometry, a less common coordination environment in U(VI), and six phosphonate moieties as shown in Figure . This structure can be best described as a "ring-in-a-well", with one end of the phosphonate moiety pointing toward the channel and the other away from the channel. The 12-crown-4, as well as the hydronium cation, are disordered in this compound, perhaps owing to static or dynamic rotational disorder of the 12-crown-4 molecule. This type of disorder is well-precedented. Attempts to model the disorder did not result in improved refinements or lower residual electron density. The triclinic space group was consistently selected by the xprep. We also tried to solve the structure using the trigonal/rhombohedral (R3̅) space group and found out that it was a false alarm.

elements.content: U12C4-2 consists of three uranyl centers, U(1), U(2), and U(3), that are coordinated by two linear oxygen atoms. The UO2 2+ cations have OUO bond angles of 179.999(1)°, 179.999(2)°, and 180.0(4)° with normal average UO bond distances of 1.746(7), 1.763(8), and 1.775(8) Å, respectively. Four oxygen atoms from phosphonate ligands are coordinated to the uranium centers at the equatorial positions. These U–O bond distances range from 2.262(7) to 2.302(8) Å. The framework is anionic, and the channels are filled with 12-crown-4 and hydronium molecules. The bond-valence sums for U(1), U(2), and U(3) are 5.97, 6.02, and 6.17, respectively. They are consistent with the formal oxidation state of U(VI). The P–O bond distances range from 1.490(8) to 1.568(10) Å. The P(1)O(5), P(2)O(9), and P(3)O(12) bond distances are 1.568(10), 1.560(10), and 1.559(10) Å. Three protonated P–OH groups are present along with partially protonated species to balance the charges.

elements.content: Some interesting observations can be drawn from the way the phosphonate and uranyl groups are coordinated in these layered structures. This one-dimensional topology has been observed in our recent communication on uranyl diphosphonate nanotubules and also in a uranyl molybdate. The structure of U18C6-1, as shown in Figure , reveals the chains of uranyl phosphonate polyhedra that are connected through the phenyl ring into uranyl sheets. The pattern observed here shows that one of the PO3 moieties of the diphosphonate ligand spans the uranyl cations to help create the dimers, while, on the other end, the PO3 moiety bridges the dimers to create one-dimensional uranyl chains. The same structural topology was observed in U18C6-2 (see Figure ) except that the phenyl rings are canted in an alternating pattern. This tilting is produced by the planar [K@(C12H24O6)]+ complex. The topology of U18C6-1 and U18C6-2 resembles what we reported in the uranyl diphosphonate nanotubule. In the U15C5-1 structure (Figure ), one diphosphonate ligand spans the uranyl cations at both PO3 moieties while another ligand bridges the dimers. The structural topology in U12C4-1 as shown in Figure is different from those of the other three compounds, U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1; the uranyl dimers shared edges via oxygen atoms in U12C4-1, whereas they are connected through the vertices by fluoride ion in the other three compounds. The fluoride ion might be connected with the observed topology in U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1. One of the PO3 moieties of the same diphosphonate ligand spans the uranyl dimers while the other PO3 moiety bridges the dimers.
elements.clean_text:
Polyhedral Representations of the Uranyl Phosphonate Environments of the Layered Structures

Some interesting observations can be drawn from the way the phosphonate and uranyl groups are coordinated in these layered structures. This one-dimensional topology has been observed in our recent communication on uranyl diphosphonate nanotubules and also in a uranyl molybdate. The structure of U18C6-1, as shown in Figure , reveals the chains of uranyl phosphonate polyhedra that are connected through the phenyl ring into uranyl sheets. The pattern observed here shows that one of the PO3 moieties of the diphosphonate ligand spans the uranyl cations to help create the dimers, while, on the other end, the PO3 moiety bridges the dimers to create one-dimensional uranyl chains. The same structural topology was observed in U18C6-2 (see Figure ) except that the phenyl rings are canted in an alternating pattern. This tilting is produced by the planar [K@(C12H24O6)]+ complex. The topology of U18C6-1 and U18C6-2 resembles what we reported in the uranyl diphosphonate nanotubule. In the U15C5-1 structure (Figure ), one diphosphonate ligand spans the uranyl cations at both PO3 moieties while another ligand bridges the dimers. The structural topology in U12C4-1 as shown in Figure  is different from those of the other three compounds, U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1; the uranyl dimers shared edges via oxygen atoms in U12C4-1, whereas they are connected through the vertices by fluoride ion in the other three compounds. The fluoride ion might be connected with the observed topology in U18C6-1, U18C6-2, and U15C5-1. One of the PO3 moieties of the same diphosphonate ligand spans the uranyl dimers while the other PO3 moiety bridges the dimers.

elements.content: The emission of green light centered near 520 nm by compounds containing UO2 2+ cations has been known for decades. This charge-transfer based emission is always related to both symmetric and antisymmetric vibrational modes of the uranyl cation, and it typically consists of a five-peak spectrum, although far more lines can be observed at low temperatures. Various factors, such as size and quality of the crystal, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, etc., are responsible for the differences in resolution of individual transitions. However, not all uranyl compounds fluoresce and the mechanism of the emission from uranyl containing compounds is complex. Clearfield and co-workers demonstrated a considerable variance in the fluorescence properties of two closely related uranyl phenylphosphonate compounds, [UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)]2·8H2O and UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O) ·2H2O, whose structural differences are based on the conformational differences of the phosphonate anions. We recently reported unusual luminescence properties in Th(IV) complex as a result of the influence of the carboxyphenylphosphonate ligand. The fluorescence spectrum of each compound and the benchmark compound, UO2(NO3)2·6H2O, were collected under the same experimental conditions and procedures and are shown in Figure . The luminescence spectra of all the prepared compounds differ from each other with respect to the shapes of the spectra, and their peak maxima positions differ from those of the benchmark compound. Five prominent peaks are clearly resolved for some of these compounds, that correspond to the electronic and vibronic transitions S11–S00 and S10–S0v (v = 0–4). As for the benchmark compound, the luminescent spectrum showed well resolved sharp vibronic peaks at 487, 509, 532, 558, 586, and 612 nm, and the most intense peak (S10–S00) is positioned at 509 nm. In contrast to the benchmark compound, five emission bands were observed at 491, 520, 543, 585, and 611 nm for U18C6-1, whereas, for U18C6-2, four emission bands were identified at 489, 543, 585, and 611 nm. The luminescent spectra of U12C4-1 and U12C4-2 were the same as that of U18C6-2. For U15C5-1, the luminescence spectrum resembles U18C5-1 with a small shift in the positions of the five emission bands, observed at 489, 515, 543, 585, and 611 nm. The most intense peaks are positioned at 543 nm for all five compounds. These compounds exhibit a slight red shift of 35 nm along with lesser intensity for the emission bands compared to the benchmark compound. The fluorescence spectra from these compounds are similar to those reported for other uranyl diphosphonate compounds. The slight difference in spectra of U18C6-1 and U15C5-1 from those of the other three compounds may be attributed to the different coordination environments around the uranium center.

This charge-transfer based emission is always related to both symmetric and antisymmetric vibrational modes of the uranyl cation, and it typically consists of a five-peak spectrum, although far more lines can be observed at low temperatures. Various factors, such as size and quality of the crystal, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, etc., are responsible for the differences in resolution of individual transitions. However, not all uranyl compounds fluoresce and the mechanism of the emission from uranyl containing compounds is complex. Clearfield and co-workers demonstrated a considerable variance in the fluorescence properties of two closely related uranyl phenylphosphonate compounds, [UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)]2⋅8H2O and UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O) ⋅2H2O, whose structural differences are based on the conformational differences of the phosphonate anions. Five prominent peaks are clearly resolved for some of these compounds, that correspond to the electronic and vibronic transitions S11-S00 and S10-S0v (v = 0-4). As for the benchmark compound, the luminescent spectrum showed well resolved sharp vibronic peaks at 487, 509, 532, 558, 586, and 612 nm, and the most intense peak (S10-S00) is positioned at 509 nm. In contrast to the benchmark compound, five emission bands were observed at 491, 520, 543, 585, and 611 nm for U18C6-1, whereas, for U18C6-2, four emission bands were identified at 489, 543, 585, and 611 nm. The luminescent spectra of U12C4-1 and U12C4-2 were the same as that of U18C6-2. The most intense peaks are positioned at 543 nm for all five compounds. These compounds exhibit a slight red shift of 35 nm along with lesser intensity for the emission bands compared to the benchmark compound. The fluorescence spectra from these compounds are similar to those reported for other uranyl diphosphonate compounds. elements.content: The low wavenumber region of the IR spectra is dominated by the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the uranyl cation, UO2 2+, ranging from about 800 to 950 cm–1. The group of peaks between 1000 cm–1 and 1200 cm–1 that overlap with peaks from crown ethers are at expected values for PO, PO asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations. The peaks in the range from 1120 to 2900 cm–1 are characteristic of crown ethers. The stretching mode of H3O+ is a very broad band around 2900 cm–1 that overlaps with sharp C–H and C–O stretching peaks of the crown ethers. The C–O–C stretching was observed around 1120–1250 cm–1. The broad bands around 3500 cm–1 are associated with free water molecules (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

The low wavenumber region of the IR spectra is dominated by the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the uranyl cation, UO2 2+, ranging from about 800 to 950 cm-1. The group of peaks between 1000 cm-1 and 1200 cm-1 that overlap with peaks from crown ethers are at expected values for PO, PO asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations. The peaks in the range from 1120 to 2900 cm-1 are characteristic of crown ethers. The stretching mode of H3O+ is a very broad band around 2900 cm-1 that overlaps with sharp C-H and C-O stretching peaks of the crown ethers. The C-O-C stretching was observed around 1120-1250 cm-1. The broad bands around 3500 cm-1 are associated with free water molecules (see ).

elements.content: The use of crown ethers for recovering of 90Sr2+ ions in acidic solution was well developed in the SREX process. The potential application of the immobilization of the crown ethers on solid supports has been examined and found to limit the solvation effects and ease the recovery of the crown ethers that are otherwise soluble in water. These materials are remarkable for their selective sorption of metal ions. They have highly flexible backbone and symmetry constraints that make them very promising hosts for the long-term storage of radionuclides found in used nuclear fuel. On the basis of previous reports on crown ethers, these materials could be used for selective sorption of cations without necessarily exchanging the crown ethers for other cations while the uranyl diphosphonate network serves as a support. The sorption studies of some selected cations on the U18C6-1 and U12C4-2 structures were examined at room temperature and 70 °C to investigate if they can serve as a good host material for cations. These studies reveal that none of these cations were removed from solution.
elements.clean_text:
Ion-Exchange Studies

The use of crown ethers for recovering of 90Sr2+ ions in acidic solution was well developed in the SREX process. The potential application of the immobilization of the crown ethers on solid supports has been examined and found to limit the solvation effects and ease the recovery of the crown ethers that are otherwise soluble in water. These materials are remarkable for their selective sorption of metal ions. They have highly flexible backbone and symmetry constraints that make them very promising hosts for the long-term storage of radionuclides found in used nuclear fuel. On the basis of previous reports on crown ethers, these materials could be used for selective sorption of cations without necessarily exchanging the crown ethers for other cations while the uranyl diphosphonate network serves as a support. The sorption studies of some selected cations on the U18C6-1 and U12C4-2 structures were examined at room temperature and 70 °C to investigate if they can serve as a good host material for cations. These studies reveal that none of these cations were removed from solution.

elements.content: The series of materials obtained through this mild hydrothermal route incorporating various crown ethers has permitted us to examine the direct relation between the sizes, shapes, charges (inclusion cations), and geometry of the resulting compounds. This project began with simple templates such as organoammonium cations and was later extended to alkali metal ions and, as reported here, hydronium–crown ether and alkali metal–crown ether inclusion complexes. One of our goals is to suggest new or modified crown ethers with the cavities or channels within crystalline lattices useful for long-term storage and selective ion exchange of radionuclides. By alteration of the crown ether from larger to smaller sizes and incorporation of alkali cations, we have shown diversity in crystal lattice of the five compounds, which vary from layered to channel structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The series of materials obtained through this mild hydrothermal route incorporating various crown ethers has permitted us to examine the direct relation between the sizes, shapes, charges (inclusion cations), and geometry of the resulting compounds. This project began with simple templates such as organoammonium cations and was later extended to alkali metal ions and, as reported here, hydronium-crown ether and alkali metal-crown ether inclusion complexes. One of our goals is to suggest new or modified crown ethers with the cavities or channels within crystalline lattices useful for long-term storage and selective ion exchange of radionuclides. By alteration of the crown ether from larger to smaller sizes and incorporation of alkali cations, we have shown diversity in crystal lattice of the five compounds, which vary from layered to channel structures.

cln_elements.content: UO2(NO3)·6H2O (50.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (47.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), 0.5 mL of water, and very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave in the presence of either 18-crown-6 (26.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), 15-crown-5 (0.02 mL, 0.1 mmol), or 12-crown-4 (0.2–0.4 mL, 1.2–2.5 mmol) to produce the above compounds, respectively. After heating for 2 days at 150 °C, the autoclave was then cooled at an average rate of 5 °C/h to 25 °C. The resulting yellow products were thoroughly washed with warm water (to remove unreacted phosphonic acid), then rinsed with ethanol, and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. U18C6-2 was isolated by the same procedure above by adding KCl (10.4 mg, 0.1 mmol). A pure phase containing U12C4-2 was isolated by using 0.4 mL of 12-crown-4. Yellow tablets of the compounds U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 and yellow needles of U15C5-1 suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were formed. (Yields are U18C6-1 = 61% and U12C4-2 = 69% based on uranium.)

U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U15C5-1, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2

UO2(NO3)⋅6H2O (50.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (47.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), 0.5 mL of water, and very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave in the presence of either 18-crown-6 (26.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), 15-crown-5 (0.02 mL, 0.1 mmol), or 12-crown-4 (0.2-0.4 mL, 1.2-2.5 mmol) to produce the above compounds, respectively. After heating for 2 days at 150 °C, the autoclave was then cooled at an average rate of 5 °C/h to 25 °C. The resulting yellow products were thoroughly washed with warm water (to remove unreacted phosphonic acid), then rinsed with ethanol, and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. U18C6-2 was isolated by the same procedure above by adding KCl (10.4 mg, 0.1 mmol). A pure phase containing U12C4-2 was isolated by using 0.4 mL of 12-crown-4. Yellow tablets of the compounds U18C6-1, U18C6-2, U12C4-1, and U12C4-2 and yellow needles of U15C5-1 suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were formed. (Yields are U18C6-1 = 61% and U12C4-2 = 69% based on uranium.)
